Authors:
Clarice Loguercio Leite, Larissa TRIERVEILER PEREIRA, Alice
GERLACH, Marisa Campos Santana, Cecilia Cristina Carmaran, Andrea Irene
Romero
Title:
Additional information on Mycocitrus aurantium
(Bionectriaceae, Hypocreales), an unusual bamboo-inhabiting fungus found
in South America
Keywords: Ascomycota; Fungal taxonomy; ITS; Neotropical fungi
Abstract:
Mycocitrus Möller is a tropical genus that comprises two
species, which form large orange stromata on bamboo culms. An ongoing
survey of macrofungi in Santa Catarina State, Brazil, has produced four
collections of Mycocitrus aurantium Möller. This species is considered
rare and few records of it are found in the literature. The goals of
this work are to improve the morphological knowledge of the species,
communicate the first culture since the finding of M. aurantium and
discuss its phylogenetic position. Morphological and phylogenetic
studies were carried out on fresh specimens and cultures. A phylogeny
was constructed based on sequences of the nuclear ribosomal internal
transcribed spacer. Currently, Mycocitrus is placed in the
Bionectriaceae (Hypocreales); however, its placement at the family level
is unclear when considering morphological characters alone.
